Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Mercury in the Atmosphere Over the Eastern United States
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project comprises the first large-scale airborne experiment focused on mercury over North America. The project has two primary objectives: 1) Constrain emissions of mercury from major source regions in the eastern United States, 2) Quantify the distribution and chemical transformations of mercury in the lower troposphere. To address these goals the NSF/National Center for Atmsopheric Research C-130 aircraft will be equipped with a suite of state-of-the-art instrumentation to measure gaseous elemental mercury (GEM), gaseous oxidized mercury (GOM), particle-bound Hg (pHg) and a suite of other compounds for air mass characterization. Flight plans will be designed to study industrial mercury sources over the Ohio River Valley, outflow of North American mercury to the Atlantic, and the impact of convective precipitation on surface wet deposition of mercury over the Southeast U.S. Operational planning will utilize regional and global forecast models to optimize the use of flight time. The C-130 observations will be integrated and analyzed after the mission with several chemical transport and Lagrangian models. These models will be used to examine the consistency between observations and emission inventories, allow the integration of ground-based observations with aircraft observations in a unified framework, constrain source-receptor relationships, and test different hypotheses about the chemical transformations and global cycling of mercury.

Human exposure to mercury is a significant health risk and a problem of national and global significance. Project results will reduce the uncertainties concerning source-receptor relationships and the relative contributions of domestic, foreign and natural sources to the inventory of atmospheric mercury over the eastern U.S. The research will involve a number of graduate and undergraduate students from several different U.S. institutions and thus will expose these students to working on high-level scientific problems of great national significance. In addition to a core group of scientists from the U.S., mercury scientists from Canada, Italy, Germany and Russia will also collaborate in the work, thus strengthening international scientific cooperation on global environmental problems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The element mercury is a potent neurotoxin. Humans are exposed to mercury primarily by eating seafood, but there are large uncertainties as to the sources of mercury. Some mercury is natural, but most of it is probably due to human emissions. Coal contains mercury and, when burned, this mercury is released into the atmosphere in gaseous or particulate form. This mercury can then be cycled and eventually end up in our food supply. The sources, chemical reactions and forms of mercury that control cycling are poorly understood. There are several forms of mercury in the atmosphere, and current technologies have significant limitations in measuring the different forms. This project addressed these technological limitations and the poor understanding of mercury cycling.

 

The primary goals for this project were:

1.  Develop new methods to measure atmospheric mercury (Hg) from an aircraft.

2.  Make measurements of atmospheric Hg in the eastern United States from a C-130 aircraft in order to understand the sources and chemistry of Hg.

3.  Identify the chemical processes that control Hg cycling in the atmosphere.

4.  Compare aircraft observations to simulations from global atmospheric transport and dispersion models as a way to test our overall understanding of Hg cycling.

This project was part of the larger Nitrogen, Oxidants, Mercury and Aerosols: Distributions, Sources and Sinks (NOMADSS) project.

The experimental work consisted of 19 flights on the National Center for Research (NCAR) C-130 aircraft in June and July of 2013. Since then, we have carefully evaluated the data, integrated the data with other measurements collected on the aircraft, analyzed the results and completed 5 published scientific papers.

Key Results

  1. Developed a new tool to make airborne observations of different chemical forms of Hg by aircraft (see Ambrose et al., 2015).
  2. Quantified emissions from coal-fired power plants (CFPPs), which are major sources of mercury in the Southeast US.                  Figure 1 shows an example of the method we used to quantify mercury emissions from power plants. In this example, the aircraft flew downwind and through the plume of the power plants while the plants were operating routinely. By comparing the concentrations of mercury with the concentrations of carbon monoxide, carbon dioxide and sulfur dioxide, we could evaluate the mercury emissions relative to these other tracers. A key conclusion is that for some CFPPs, including some of the largest Hg emitters in the country, the observations suggest substantially higher Hg emissions than the national emission inventories (see Ambrose et al., 2015, for more information).
  3. Analyzed Hg emissions from the Chicago-Gary metropolitan area.                                                                                                            The Chicago-Gary area is highly industrialized with significant emissions of mercury and other pollutants. Using data from NOMADSS research flight 15, we developed a novel method to evaluate the Hg emission inventory from this region. Figure 2 shows the NCAR C-130 aircraft flight track as it passed downwind of the Chicago-Gary area. The observations showed a region of enhanced Hg, carbon monoxide, sulfur dioxide and nitrogen oxides. Combining the observations with the FLEXPART transport and dispersion model allowed us to characterize the “footprint” of the observations and therefore make a good comparison between the observations and expectations based on the emission inventory. Our analysis indicated “that there are many small emission sources that are not fully accounted for within the inventory, and/or that the re-emission of legacy Hg is a significant source of THg to the atmosphere in this region” (see Gratz et al., 2016, for more information).
  4.  Identified the origin of highly oxidized Hg in the free troposphere.  On several flights, substantial concentrations of gaseous oxidized mercury were observed. This is a reactive form of mercury that plays a key role in the global processing of mercury. Through observations, extensive analysis and simulations with models, we concluded that this compound was formed through oxidation by bromine radical compounds. This is a major finding and has implications for the global cycling of mercury (see Gratz et al., 2015, and Shah et al., 2016, for more information).
  5. Completed further analyses using the airborne mercury data along with global mercury transport models.                                    The combination of observations and model analyses helps explain the global cycling and source-receptor relationships (see Shah et al., 2016, and Song et al., 2016, for more information

 

 Broader impacts:

The NOMADSS data can be used to better understand sources and sinks of mercury in the U.S.  In addition, several students and post-doctoral fellows received valuable training in making atmospheric observations, running atmospheric models, interpreting the data and publishing scientific papers.
